CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel. Rho-1 GABA receptor could play a role in retinal
CC       neurotransmission.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho. Interacts
CC       with SQSTM1 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P24046-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P24046-2; Sequence=VSP_036363;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=P24046-3; Sequence=VSP_046665;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in the retina and in a lesser
CC       extent in brain, lung and thymus.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       GABRR1 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:

CC       Sequence=AAI30345.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC       inhibition by binding to the GABA receptor and opening an integral
CC       chloride channel.

CC       membrane protein.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter, mediates neuronal
CC       inhibition by binding to the GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and
CC       opening an integral chloride channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the heteropentameric receptor for GABA, the
CC       major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the vertebrate brain.
CC       Functions also as histamine receptor and mediates cellular
CC       responses to histamine. Functions as receptor for diazepines and
CC       various anesthetics, such as pentobarbital; these are bound at a
CC       separate allosteric effector binding site. Functions as ligand-
CC       gated chloride channel. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18281286,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18514161, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22243422,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22303015, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24909990,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26950270}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heteropentamer, formed by a combination of alpha, beta,
CC       gamma, delta and rho chains (PubMed:22243422, PubMed:18281286,
CC       PubMed:18514161, PubMed:24909990). Can form functional
CC       homopentamers (in vitro) (PubMed:22303015). Interacts with UBQLN1
CC       (By similarity). May interact with KIF21B (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63079, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18281286,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18514161, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22243422,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22303015, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24909990}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-6258252, EBI-6258252;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24909990}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18281286, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18514161,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22243422, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22303015,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24909990, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26950270}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24909990}. Cytoplasmic
CC       vesicle membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63079}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC         Comment=Isoforms differ in their signal region.;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P28472-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P28472-2; Sequence=VSP_000088;
CC         Note=Variant in position: 11:P->S (in ECA5, the mutant protein
CC         is hyperglycosylated and has reduced mean current densities
CC         compared to wild-type, dbSNP:rs25409). Variant in position:
CC         15:S->F (in ECA5, the mutant protein is hyperglycosylated and
CC         has reduced mean current densities compared to wild-type).
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18514161};
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=P28472-3; Sequence=VSP_046126;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=P28472-4; Sequence=VSP_046676;
CC   -!- POLYMORPHISM: GABRB3 variants may be associated with insomnia, a
CC       condition of inability to initiate or maintain sleep [MIM:137192].
CC   -!- DISEASE: Epilepsy, childhood absence 5 (ECA5) [MIM:612269]: A
CC       subtype of idiopathic generalized epilepsy characterized by an
CC       onset at age 6-7 years, frequent absence seizures (several per
CC       day) and bilateral, synchronous, symmetric 3-Hz spike waves on
CC       EEG. Tonic-clonic seizures often develop in adolescence. Absence
CC       seizures may either remit or persist into adulthood.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18514161, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22303015}.
CC       Note=Disease susceptibility is associated with variations
CC       affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Epileptic encephalopathy, early infantile, 43 (EIEE43)
CC       [MIM:617113]: A form of epileptic encephalopathy, a heterogeneous
CC       group of severe childhood onset epilepsies characterized by
CC       refractory seizures, neurodevelopmental impairment, and poor
CC       prognosis. Development is normal prior to seizure onset, after
CC       which cognitive and motor delays become apparent. EIEE43
CC       inheritance is autosomal dominant. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23934111,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25356899, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26950270,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26993267, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27476654,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27864847}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       GABRB3 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds UBQLN1 (By similarity). Generally pentameric. There
CC       are five types of GABA(A) receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma,
CC       delta, and rho. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Only found in cerebellar granule cells.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       GABRA6 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated chloride channel. Chloride channels have
CC       several functions including the regulation of cell volume;
CC       membrane potential stabilization, signal transduction and
CC       transepithelial transport. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12456816,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22521272, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26007199,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26502825, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26510092,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7951242, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8112288,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9122265, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9736777}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26502825}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q92624:APPBP2; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-10206780, EBI-743771;
CC       Q8IZU0:FAM9B; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-10206780, EBI-10175124;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26502825};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in skeletal muscles.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Myotonia congenita, autosomal dominant (MCAD)
CC       [MIM:160800]: A non-dystrophic skeletal muscle disorder
CC       characterized by muscle stiffness and an inability of the muscle
CC       to relax after voluntary contraction. Most patients have symptom
CC       onset in the legs, which later progresses to the arms, neck, and
CC       facial muscles. Many patients show marked hypertrophy of the lower
CC       limb muscles. The autosomal dominant form (Thomsen disease) is
CC       less common and less severe than the autosomal recessive one
CC       (Becker disease). A milder form of autosomal dominant myotonia is
CC       characterized by isolated myotonia without muscle weakness,
CC       hypotrophy, or hypertrophy (myotonia levior).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12661046, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26096614,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27653901, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27666773,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7581380, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7981750,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8112288, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8533761,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8845168, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9122265,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9566422, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9736777}. Note=The
CC       disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in
CC       this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Myotonia congenita, autosomal recessive (MCAR)
CC       [MIM:255700]: A non-dystrophic skeletal muscle disorder
CC       characterized by muscle stiffness and an inability of the muscle
CC       to relax after voluntary contraction. Most patients have symptom
CC       onset in the legs, which later progresses to the arms, neck, and
CC       facial muscles. Many patients show marked hypertrophy of the lower
CC       limb muscles. The autosomal recessive form (Becker disease) is
CC       more severe than the autosomal dominant one (Thomsen disease).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10215406, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10644771,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11113225, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12661046,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1379744, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19697366,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22521272, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22641783,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26007199, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26096614,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26502825, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26510092,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7874130, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7951242,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7981681, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8533761,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8571958, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8845168,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9566422, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9736777}. Note=The
CC       disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in
CC       this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The CLC channel family contains both chloride
CC       channels and proton-coupled anion transporters that exchange
CC       chloride or another anion for protons. The absence of conserved
CC       gating glutamate residues is typical for family members that
CC       function as channels.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel (TC 2.A.49) family.
CC       ClC-1/CLCN1 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [7]
RP   DISEASE, AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=16672662; DOI=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.3991-05.2006;
RA   Graham B.A., Schofield P.R., Sah P., Margrie T.W., Callister R.J.;
RT   "Distinct physiological mechanisms underlie altered glycinergic
RT   synaptic transmission in the murine mutants spastic, spasmodic, and

RN   [8]
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=19723286; DOI=10.1111/j.1460-9568.2009.06903.x;
RA   Eichler S.A., Foerstera B., Smolinsky B., Juettner R., Lehmann T.N.,
RA   Faehling M., Schwarz G., Legendre P., Meier J.C.;
RT   "Splice-specific roles of glycine receptor alpha3 in the
RT   hippocampus.";
RL   Eur. J. Neurosci. 30:1077-1091(2009).
RN   [9]
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=22592841; DOI=10.1002/cne.23139;
RA   Weltzien F., Puller C., O'Sullivan G.A., Paarmann I., Betz H.;
RT   "Distribution of the glycine receptor beta-subunit in the mouse CNS as
RT   revealed by a novel monoclonal antibody.";
RL   J. Comp. Neurol. 520:3962-3981(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glycine receptors are ligand-gated chloride channels.
CC       GLRB does not form ligand-gated ion channels by itself, but is
CC       part of heteromeric ligand-gated chloride channels. Channel
CC       opening is triggered by extracellular glycine (PubMed:12809985).
CC       Heteropentameric channels composed of GLRB and GLRA1 are activated
CC       by lower glycine levels than homopentameric GLRA1. Plays an
CC       important role in the down-regulation of neuronal excitability.
CC       Contributes to the generation of inhibitory postsynaptic currents
CC       (PubMed:12809985, PubMed:16672662). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48167,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12809985, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16672662}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heteropentamer composed of GLRB and GLRA1. Heteropentamer
CC       composed of GLRB and GLRA2. Heteropentamer composed of GLRB and
CC       GLRA3. Heteropentamer composed of two GLRA1 and three GLRB
CC       subunits. Heteropentamer composed of three GLRA1 and two GLRB
CC       subunits. Interacts with GPHN. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48167}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q03555:Gphn (xeno); NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-7069198, EBI-349317;
CC       Q8BUV3:Gphn; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-7069198, EBI-771218;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22592841}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48167}. Cell junction, synapse
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19723286, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22592841}. Cell
CC       projection, dendrite {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19723286}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12809985}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P23415}. Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48167}. Note=Retained in the cytoplasm
CC       upon heterologous expression by itself. Coexpression with GPHN
CC       promotes expression at the cell membrane. Coexpression with GLRA1,
CC       GLRA2 or GLRA3 promotes expression at the cell membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P20781}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in spinal cord, brain and brain stem,
CC       especially in the periolivary region, spinal nuclei, trigeminal
CC       nucleus, medulla oblongata, pons and midbrain. Detected in the
CC       inner plexiform layer of the retina (at protein level)
CC       (PubMed:22592841). High levels of expression in cortex,
CC       hippocampus, thalamus and cerebellum (PubMed:7920630). Detected in
CC       spinal cord (PubMed:7946325). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22592841,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7920630, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7946325}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Note=Defects in Glrb cause the spastic condition which is
CC       characterized by muscle rigidity, tremors, myoclonic jerks,
CC       pronounced startle reaction, abnormal gait and impaired righting
CC       ability (PubMed:7920630). Neurons from the ventral horn of the
CC       spinal cord display reduced inhibitory postsynaptic currents
CC       (PubMed:12809985). Likewise, hypoglossal neurons display a
CC       dramatic reduction in the frequency and amplitude of postsynaptic
CC       inhibitory currents (PubMed:16672662).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12809985, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16672662,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7920630}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Glycine receptor (TC 1.A.9.3) subfamily. GLRB sub-
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   VARIANT [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] ARG-516.
RX   PubMed=16959974; DOI=10.1126/science.1133427;
RA   Sjoeblom T., Jones S., Wood L.D., Parsons D.W., Lin J., Barber T.D.,
RA   Mandelker D., Leary R.J., Ptak J., Silliman N., Szabo S.,

RA   Vogelstein B., Kinzler K.W., Velculescu V.E.;
RT   "The consensus coding sequences of human breast and colorectal
RT   cancers.";
RL   Science 314:268-274(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: The alpha4 beta2 gamma 2L receptor is not repressed by
CC       diazepam. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8719416}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       GABRA4 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Protein Spotlight; Note=Forbidden fruit - Issue
CC       56 of March 2005;
CC       URL="https://web.expasy.org/spotlight/back_issues/056";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated chloride channel. Chloride channels have
CC       several functions including the regulation of cell volume;
CC       membrane potential stabilization, signal transduction and
CC       transepithelial transport. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19153159,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19191339}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P35525}; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P51788-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P51788-2; Sequence=VSP_007831, VSP_007832, VSP_036455;
CC         Note=May be produced at very low levels due to a premature stop
CC         codon in the mRNA, leading to nonsense-mediated mRNA decay.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=P51788-3; Sequence=VSP_036456;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=P51788-4; Sequence=VSP_045457;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=P51788-5; Sequence=VSP_045458;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Ubiquitously expressed. Moderately expressed
CC       in aortic and coronary vascular smooth muscle cells and expressed
CC       at a low level in aortic endothelial cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10198195}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated. Activated by dephosphorylation.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P35525}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Epilepsy, idiopathic generalized 11 (EIG11) [MIM:607628]:
CC       A disorder characterized by recurring generalized seizures in the
CC       absence of detectable brain lesions and/or metabolic
CC       abnormalities. Generalized seizures arise diffusely and
CC       simultaneously from both hemispheres of the brain.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19191339}. Note=Disease susceptibility is
CC       associated with variations affecting the gene represented in this
CC       entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Juvenile absence epilepsy 2 (JAE2) [MIM:607628]: A
CC       subtype of idiopathic generalized epilepsy characterized by onset
CC       occurring around puberty, absence seizures, generalized tonic-
CC       clonic seizures (GTCS), GTCS on awakening, and myoclonic seizures.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12612585, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19710712}.
CC       Note=Disease susceptibility may be associated with variations
CC       affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 8 (EJM8) [MIM:607628]: A
CC       subtype of idiopathic generalized epilepsy. Patients have afebrile
CC       seizures only, with onset in adolescence (rather than in
CC       childhood) and myoclonic jerks which usually occur after awakening
CC       and are triggered by sleep deprivation and fatigue.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19191339}. Note=Disease susceptibility is
CC       associated with variations affecting the gene represented in this
CC       entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Leukoencephalopathy with ataxia (LKPAT) [MIM:615651]: An
CC       autosomal recessive neurologic disorder with a characteristic
CC       pattern of white matter abnormalities on brain MRI. Affected
CC       individuals have prominent signal abnormalities and decreased
CC       apparent diffusion coefficient values in the posterior limbs of
CC       the internal capsules, middle cerebral peduncles, pyramidal tracts
CC       in the pons, and middle cerebellar peduncles, suggesting myelin
CC       microvacuolation. Clinical features include ataxia and unstable
CC       gait. More variable abnormalities may include visual field
CC       defects, headaches, and learning disabilities.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23707145}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The CLC channel family contains both chloride
CC       channels and proton-coupled anion transporters that exchange
CC       chloride or another anion for protons. The absence of conserved
CC       gating glutamate residues is typical for family members that
CC       function as channels (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel (TC 2.A.49) family.
CC       ClC-2/CLCN2 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAH21578.1; Type=Erroneous translation; Note=Wrong choice of frame.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RN   [11]
RP   VARIANT BARTS4B CYS-80.
RX   PubMed=15044642; DOI=10.1056/NEJMoa032843;
RA   Schlingmann K.P., Konrad M., Jeck N., Waldegger P., Reinalter S.C.,
RA   Holder M., Seyberth H.W., Waldegger S.;
RT   "Salt wasting and deafness resulting from mutations in two chloride
RT   channels.";
RL   N. Engl. J. Med. 350:1314-1319(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated chloride channel. Chloride channels have
CC       several functions including the regulation of cell volume;
CC       membrane potential stabilization, signal transduction and
CC       transepithelial transport. May be important in urinary
CC       concentrating mechanisms.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Activated by extracellular calcium and
CC       inhibited by extracellular protons. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:23148261}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer (PubMed:17562318). Interacts with BSND. Forms
CC       heteromers with BSND in the thin ascending limb of Henle (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9WUB7,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17562318}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12538872, EBI-12538872;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P51800-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P51800-2; Sequence=VSP_044700;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=P51800-3; Sequence=VSP_045795;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed predominantly in the kidney. All
CC       nephron segments expressing BSND also express CLCNK proteins.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11734858}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Bartter syndrome 4B, neonatal, with sensorineural
CC       deafness (BARTS4B) [MIM:613090]: A digenic form of Bartter
CC       syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by
CC       impaired salt reabsorption in the thick ascending loop of Henle
CC       with pronounced salt wasting, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, and
CC       varying degrees of hypercalciuria. BARTS4B is associated with
CC       sensorineural deafness. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15044642,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18310267}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting distinct genetic loci, including the gene
CC       represented in this entry. Loss-of-function of both CLCNKA and
CC       CLCNKB results in the disease phenotype (PubMed:18310267).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18310267}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel (TC 2.A.49) family.
CC       CLCNKA subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RT   "Mutations in the chloride channel gene, CLCNKB, cause Bartter's
RT   syndrome type III.";
RL   Nat. Genet. 17:171-178(1997).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated chloride channel. Chloride channels have
CC       several functions including the regulation of cell volume;
CC       membrane potential stabilization, signal transduction and
CC       transepithelial transport. May be important in urinary
CC       concentrating mechanisms. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11734858}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with BSND. Forms heteromers with BSND in the
CC       thick ascending limb of Henle and more distal segments (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P51801-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P51801-2; Sequence=VSP_045965, VSP_045966, VSP_045967;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed predominantly in the kidney.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11734858}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Bartter syndrome 3 (BARTS3) [MIM:607364]: A form of
CC       Bartter syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by
CC       impaired salt reabsorption in the thick ascending loop of Henle
CC       with pronounced salt wasting, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, and
CC       varying degrees of hypercalciuria. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9326936}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Bartter syndrome 4B, neonatal, with sensorineural
CC       deafness (BARTS4B) [MIM:613090]: A digenic form of Bartter
CC       syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by
CC       impaired salt reabsorption in the thick ascending loop of Henle
CC       with pronounced salt wasting, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, and
CC       varying degrees of hypercalciuria. BARTS4B is associated with
CC       sensorineural deafness. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15044642,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18310267}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting distinct genetic loci, including the gene
CC       represented in this entry. Loss-of-function of both CLCNKA and
CC       CLCNKB results in the disease phenotype (PubMed:18310267).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18310267}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Compared with CLCNKA/BSND, CLCNKB/BSND is more
CC       sensitive to pH and less responsive to Ca(2+).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel (TC 2.A.49) family.
CC       CLCNKB subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RT   "Molecular basis of claudin-17 anion selectivity.";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Channel-forming tight junction protein with selectivity
CC       for anions, including chloride and bicarbonate, and for solutes
CC       smaller than 9 Angstrom in diameter. In the kidney proximal
CC       tubule, may be involved in quantitative reabsorption of filtered
CC       anions. Does not affect water permeability.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22402829}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with OCLN (PubMed:20375010).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375010}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, tight junction
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22402829}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375010}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: In the kidney, expressed in the proximal
CC       tubule and in the Henle's loop. In the distal convoluted tubule,
CC       not expressed in all tubules. Not detected in the collecting duct
CC       (at protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22402829}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the claudin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAQ88461.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=31; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

DE   RecName: Full=Glutamate-gated chloride channel subunit beta;
DE            Short=Glu-Cl subunit beta;
DE   AltName: Full=Avermectin-sensitive glutamate-gated chloride channel subunit;
DE   AltName: Full=HG4;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
OS   Haemonchus contortus (Barber pole worm).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Nematoda; Chromadorea; Rhabditida;
OC   Strongylida; Trichostrongyloidea; Haemonchidae; Haemonchinae;
OC   Haemonchus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=6289;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=9879896; DOI=10.1016/S0166-6851(98)00148-0;
RA   Delany N.S., Laughton D.L., Wolstenholme A.J.;
RT   "Cloning and localisation of an avermectin receptor-related subunit
RT   from Haemonchus contortus.";
RL   Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 97:177-187(1998).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated chloride channel subunit; channel
CC       properties may be modulated by the formation of heteromeric
CC       channels. Glutamate binding triggers a rapidly reversible current,
CC       while the anti-helmintic drug ivermectin triggers a permanently
CC       open channel configuration. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:G5EBR3}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:G5EBR3}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q94900}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q94900}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q94900}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q94900}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in motor neuron commissures at the
CC       anterior portion of the worms. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9879896}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Glutamate-gated chloride channel (TC 1.A.9.4) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated chloride channel that could play a role in
CC       the regulation of nitrate content. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10758477}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer (By similarity). Interacts with PP2A5
CC       (PubMed:27676158). {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27676158}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=1;
CC         Comment=A number of isoforms are produced. According to EST
CC         sequences.;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P92941-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Broadly expressed in the plant.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: In shoots and roots by nitrate treatment.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10758477}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Loss-of-function mutation clca-1 leads to an
CC       altered nitrate content and hypersensitivity to chlorate.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10758477}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel (TC 2.A.49) family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH GRD.
RX   PubMed=15148245; DOI=10.1038/sj.bjp.0705818;
RA   Gisselmann G., Plonka J., Pusch H., Hatt H.;
RT   "Drosophila melanogaster GRD and LCCH3 subunits form heteromultimeric
RT   GABA-gated cation channels.";
RL   Br. J. Pharmacol. 142:409-413(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter, mediates neuronal
CC       inhibition by binding to the GABA receptor and opening an integral
CC       chloride channel. Combines with the ligand-gated ion channel
CC       subunit GRD to form cation-selective GABA-gated ion channels when
CC       coexpressed in Xenopus laevis oocytes.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15148245}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho. Interacts
CC       with Grd (alpha chain). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15148245}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Taoka M., Takahashi N., Isobe T.;
RT   "Proteomics reveals N-linked glycoprotein diversity in Caenorhabditis
RT   elegans and suggests an atypical translocation mechanism for integral
RT   membrane proteins.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 6:2100-2109(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated chloride channel subunit; channel
CC       properties depend on the subunit composition. Glutamate binding
CC       triggers a rapidly reversible current in heteromeric channels
CC       formed by glc-1 and glc-2, while the anti-helmintic drug
CC       ivermectin and other avermectins trigger a permanently open
CC       channel configuration. Channels containing only glc-2 are
CC       activated by glutamate, but not by ivermectin (in vitro). The
CC       heteromeric channel formed by glc-1 and glc-2 is also activated by
CC       ibotenate, and it is blocked by picrotoxin and flufenamic acid
CC       (PubMed:7935817). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7935817}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer (By similarity). Homooligomer that can form
CC       functional heterooligomers with glc-1 (PubMed:7935817).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:G5EBR3, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7935817}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q94900}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q94900}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000255, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7935817}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7935817}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Glutamate-gated chloride channel (TC 1.A.9.4) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acetylcholine-gated chloride channel subunit. Currents
CC       in channels are triggered in response to acetylcholine. Channel
CC       properties may be modulated by the formation of homomeric and
CC       heteromeric channels. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homopentamer (in vitro). May interact with either acc-3
CC       or acc-4; the interactions do not result in significant
CC       heteropentameric ion channel activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in RIA, RIG, PHA and AIZ
CC       glutamatergic neurons, URX and RIH cholinergic neurons, and in
CC       male-specific MCM neurons. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26705699}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Grossly normal movement.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RT   "Specific resistance to Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection in zebrafish
RT   is mediated by the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance

RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND MUTAGENESIS OF 205-SER-PRO-206.
RX   PubMed=23487313; DOI=10.1242/dev.091819;

RA   Roxo-Rosa M., Jacinto R., Sampaio P., Lopes S.S.;
RT   "The zebrafish Kupffer's vesicle as a model system for the molecular
RT   mechanisms by which the lack of Polycystin-2 leads to stimulation of

RN   [7]
RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, DEVELOPMENTAL
RP   STAGE, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=25592226; DOI=10.1016/j.ydbio.2014.12.034;
RA   Navis A., Bagnat M.;
RT   "Loss of cftr function leads to pancreatic destruction in larval
RT   zebrafish.";
RL   Dev. Biol. 399:237-248(2015).
RN   [8]
RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (3.73 ANGSTROMS), CATALYTIC ACTIVITY,
RP   TOPOLOGY, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES.
RX   PubMed=27912062; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2016.11.014;
RA   Zhang Z., Chen J.;
RT   "Atomic structure of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance
RT   regulator.";
RL   Cell 167:1586-1597(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Epithelial ion channel that plays an important role in
CC       the regulation of epithelial ion and water transport and fluid
CC       homeostasis (PubMed:20933420, PubMed:23487313, PubMed:25592226).
CC       Mediates the transport of chloride ions across the cell membrane
CC       (By similarity). Channel activity is coupled to ATP hydrolysis.
CC       The ion channel is also permeable to HCO(3-); selectivity depends
CC       on the extracellular chloride concentration. Exerts its function
CC       also by modulating the activity of other ion channels and
CC       transporters. Contributes to the regulation of the pH and the ion
CC       content of the epithelial fluid layer (By similarity). Required
CC       for normal fluid homeostasis in the gut (PubMed:20933420).
CC       Required for normal volume expansion of Kupffer's vesicle during
CC       embryonic development and for normal establishment of left-right
CC       body patterning (PubMed:23487313, PubMed:26432887). Required for
CC       normal resistance to infection by P.aeruginosa strain PA14 and
CC       strain SMC573 (PubMed:20732993). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P13569,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20732993, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20933420,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23487313, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:25592226}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + H(2)O = ADP + phosphate.
CC       {ECO:0000255|RuleBase:RU362037, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27912062}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=0.22 mM for ATP {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27912062};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer; does not require oligomerization for channel
CC       activity (By similarity). Interacts with cse1l; this interaction
CC       may downregulate cftr activity (PubMed:20933420).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P13569, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20933420}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Apical cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20933420, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23487313,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25592226}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27912062}. Early endosome membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P13569}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27912062}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23487313, ECO:0000305|PubMed:27912062}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27912062}. Recycling
CC       endosome membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P13569}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27912062}. Endoplasmic
CC       reticulum membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P13569}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27912062}. Note=The channel
CC       is internalized from the cell surface into an endosomal recycling
CC       compartment, from where it is recycled to the cell membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P13569}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in gut epithelium (at protein level)
CC       (PubMed:20933420). Detected in kidney, spleen, intestine and liver
CC       (PubMed:20732993). Detected in pancreatic duct epithelium at 5 dpf
CC       and throughout adult life (PubMed:25592226).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20732993, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25592226}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: First detected in developing pancreatic duct
CC       at 3 dpf (PubMed:25592226). Detected on Kupffer's vesicle during
CC       embryonic development (PubMed:23487313, PubMed:26432887). Detected
CC       on neural floorplate, brain and pronephric duct primordia in
CC       embryos at the 10 somite stage (PubMed:26432887).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23487313, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25592226,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Binds and hydrolyzes ATP via the two cytoplasmic ABC
CC       transporter nucleotide-binding domains. The two ATP-binding
CC       domains interact with each other, forming a head-to-tail dimer.
CC       Normal ATPase activity requires interaction between the two
CC       domains. The first ABC transporter nucleotide-binding domain has
CC       no ATPase activity by itself. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P13569,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P26361}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The R region is intrinsically disordered. It mediates
CC       channel activation when it is phosphorylated, but not in the
CC       absence of phosphorylation. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P13569}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated; this activates the channel (PubMed:27912062).
CC       Dephosphorylation strongly decreases ATPase activity
CC       (PubMed:27912062). Phosphorylation at PKA sites activates the
CC       channel. Phosphorylation at PKC sites enhances the response to
CC       phosphorylation by PKA (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P13569, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27912062}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Considerable lethality around 10 dpf
CC       (PubMed:25592226). No effect on initial pancreas development, but
CC       at 16 dpf mutants display loss of pancreatic acinar tissue
CC       (PubMed:25592226). At 22 dpf, most pancreatic acinar tissue has
CC       disappeared and has been replaced by fibrotic tissue that
CC       surrounds dilated, mucus-filled ducts (PubMed:25592226).
CC       Morpholino knockdown of the protein in 48 hpf embryos leads to
CC       impaired resistance to P.aeruginosa strain PA14 and strain SMC573,
CC       as shown by the increased bacterial burden, but there is no effect
CC       on resistance to E.tarda, B.cenocepacia, S.aureus MZ100, E.coli
CC       XL-10 and H.influenzae Hib EAGAN (PubMed:20732993). Morpholino
CC       knockdown of the protein causes an importanr reduction of the
CC       volume of Kupffer's vesicle during embryonic development
CC       (PubMed:26432887). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20732993,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25592226, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Mutations that lead to the production of a severely
CC       truncated protein that ends before the start of the fourth
CC       transmembrane domain disrupt normal left-right body patterning
CC       during embryogenesis and abolish lumen expansion of Kupffer's
CC       vesicle. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23487313}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ABC transporter superfamily. ABCC
CC       family. CFTR transporter (TC 3.A.1.202) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000255|RuleBase:RU362037}.

CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

AC   Q21005;

RT   Caenorhabditis elegans.";

RN   [3] {ECO:0000305}
RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=26705699; DOI=10.7554/eLife.12432;
RA   Pereira L., Kratsios P., Serrano-Saiz E., Sheftel H., Mayo A.E.,
RA   Hall D.H., White J.G., LeBoeuf B., Garcia L.R., Alon U., Hobert O.;
RT   "A cellular and regulatory map of the cholinergic nervous system of C.
RT   elegans.";
RL   Elife 4:12432-12477(2015).
RN   [4] {ECO:0000305}
RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=27782882; DOI=10.7554/eLife.21734;
RA   Takayanagi-Kiya S., Zhou K., Jin Y.;
RT   "Release-dependent feedback inhibition by a presynaptically localized
RT   ligand-gated anion channel.";
RL   Elife 5:21734-21749(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acetylcholine-gated chloride channel subunit. Forms
CC       functional homopentameric (in vitro) and functional
CC       heteropentameric ion channels with acc-3 and acc-4 ion channel
CC       subunits. Currents in channels are triggered in response to
CC       acetylcholine, but not in response to GABA, glutamate, glycine,
CC       histamine or dopamine. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homopentamer (in vitro). Forms heteropentamers composed
CC       of acc-1 and acc-4 or acc-1 and acc-3. Both homopentamers and
CC       heteropentamers form functional ion channels.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in a subset of cholinergic motor
CC       neurons including cholinergic motor neurons in the ventral cord,
CC       the retrovesicular ganglion and in head neurons such as the SMD,
CC       RMD motor neurons, the AVA and AVE command interneurons and the
CC       SAA neurons. Also expressed in a small number of glutamatergic
CC       neurons including the pharyngeal neurons MI and M3, the PLM
CC       neurons and a pair of neurons in the lateral ganglion.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26705699}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Grossly normal movement.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH LCCH3.
RX   PubMed=15148245; DOI=10.1038/sj.bjp.0705818;
RA   Gisselmann G., Plonka J., Pusch H., Hatt H.;
RT   "Drosophila melanogaster GRD and LCCH3 subunits form heteromultimeric
RT   GABA-gated cation channels.";
RL   Br. J. Pharmacol. 142:409-413(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter, mediates neuronal
CC       inhibition by binding to the GABA receptor and opening an integral
CC       chloride channel. May combine with the ligand-gated ion channel
CC       subunit Lcch3 to form cation-selective GABA-gated ion channels.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15148245}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho. Interacts
CC       with Lcch3 (beta chain). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15148245}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].

RX   PubMed=24275569; DOI=10.1016/j.jprot.2013.11.014;

RN   [17]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=25944712; DOI=10.1002/pmic.201400617;
RA   Vaca Jacome A.S., Rabilloud T., Schaeffer-Reiss C., Rompais M.,
RA   Ayoub D., Lane L., Bairoch A., Van Dorsselaer A., Carapito C.;
RT   "N-terminome analysis of the human mitochondrial proteome.";
RL   Proteomics 15:2519-2524(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Small-conductance calcium-activated nonselective cation
CC       (SCAN) channel which acts as a regulator of phospholipid
CC       scrambling in platelets and osteoblasts. Phospholipid scrambling
CC       results in surface exposure of phosphatidylserine which in
CC       platelets is essential to trigger the clotting system whereas in
CC       osteoblasts is essential for the deposition of hydroxyapatite
CC       during bone mineralization. Has calcium-dependent phospholipid
CC       scramblase activity; scrambles phosphatidylserine,
CC       phosphatidylcholine and galactosylceramide (By similarity). Can
CC       generate outwardly rectifying chloride channel currents in airway
CC       epithelial cells and Jurkat T lymphocytes.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q6P9J9, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20056604,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107324, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21908539,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22006324, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22946059}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Exhibits synergistic gating by Ca(2+) and
CC       voltage. Inhibited by some non-specific cation channel blockers
CC       such as: ruthenium red, 2-aminoethyl diphenylborinate (2APB),
CC       gadolinium and cadmium ions (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20056604,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107324, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22075693,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22946059}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20056604, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107324,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22075693, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22946059}.
CC       Note=Shows an intracellular localization according to
CC       PubMed:22075693.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q4KMQ2-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q4KMQ2-2; Sequence=VSP_042893;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q4KMQ2-3; Sequence=VSP_046819;
CC         Note=Gene prediction based on EST data.;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q4KMQ2-4; Sequence=VSP_046820;
CC         Note=Gene prediction based on EST data.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in embryonic stem cell, fetal liver,
CC       retina, chronic myologenous leukemia and intestinal cancer.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15067359}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Scott syndrome (SCTS) [MIM:262890]: A mild bleeding
CC       disorder due to impaired surface exposure of procoagulant
CC       phosphatidylserine (PS) on platelets and other blood cells,
CC       following activation with Ca(2+)-elevating agents.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107324}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The term 'anoctamin' was coined because these
CC       channels are anion selective and have eight (OCT) transmembrane
CC       segments. There is some dissatisfaction in the field with the Ano
CC       nomenclature because it is not certain that all the members of
CC       this family are anion channels or have the 8-transmembrane
CC       topology.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the anoctamin family. {ECO:0000305}.

DE   RecName: Full=Chloride intracellular channel protein 1;
GN   Name=CLIC1;
OS   Bos taurus (Bovine).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Mammalia; Eutheria; Laurasiatheria; Cetartiodactyla; Ruminantia;
OC   Pecora; Bovidae; Bovinae; Bos.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=9913;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RX   PubMed=16305752; DOI=10.1186/1471-2164-6-166;
RA   Harhay G.P., Sonstegard T.S., Keele J.W., Heaton M.P., Clawson M.L.,
RA   Snelling W.M., Wiedmann R.T., Van Tassell C.P., Smith T.P.L.;
RT   "Characterization of 954 bovine full-CDS cDNA sequences.";
RL   BMC Genomics 6:166-166(2005).
RN   [2]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RC   STRAIN=Crossbred X Angus; TISSUE=Ileum;
RG   NIH - Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC) project;
RL   Submitted (AUG-2005) to the EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ databases.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Can insert into membranes and form chloride ion
CC       channels. Channel activity depends on the pH. Membrane insertion
CC       seems to be redox-regulated and may occur only under oxydizing
CC       conditions (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer. Homodimer (in vitro). Interacts with TRAPPC2.
CC       Dimerization requires a conformation change that leads to the
CC       exposure of a large hydrophobic surface. In vivo, this may lead to
CC       membrane insertion (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Single-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Single-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}. Note=Mostly in the nucleus
CC       including in the nuclear membrane. Small amount in the cytoplasm
CC       and the plasma membrane. Exists both as soluble cytoplasmic
CC       protein and as membrane protein with probably a single
CC       transmembrane domain (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Members of this family may change from a globular, soluble
CC       state to a state where the N-terminal domain is inserted into the
CC       membrane and functions as chloride channel. A conformation change
CC       of the N-terminal domain is thought to expose hydrophobic surfaces
CC       that trigger membrane insertion (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel CLIC family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-107 AND SER-196, AND
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=24275569; DOI=10.1016/j.jprot.2013.11.014;
RA   Bian Y., Song C., Cheng K., Dong M., Wang F., Huang J., Sun D.,
RA   Wang L., Ye M., Zou H.;
RT   "An enzyme assisted RP-RPLC approach for in-depth analysis of human
RT   liver phosphoproteome.";
RL   J. Proteomics 96:253-262(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium-activated chloride channel (CaCC) which plays a
CC       role in transepithelial anion transport and smooth muscle
CC       contraction. Required for the normal functioning of the
CC       interstitial cells of Cajal (ICCs) which generate electrical
CC       pacemaker activity in gastrointestinal smooth muscles. Acts as a
CC       major contributor to basal and stimulated chloride conductance in
CC       airway epithelial cells and plays an important role in tracheal
CC       cartilage development. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20056604,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21984732, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22178883,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22946059}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: ATP and calmodulin are essential for its
CC       activation. Channel activity is inhibited by CFTR protein and by
CC       chloride inhibitors such as niflumic acid (NFA) and 4,4'-
CC       diisothiocyanatostilbene-2,2'-disulfonic acid (DIDS).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22178883}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer (PubMed:21056985). Interacts with CFTR
CC       (PubMed:22178883). Interacts with TRPV4 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8BHY3, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21056985,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22178883}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15215166,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20056604, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21984732,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22178883, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22946059}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}. Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16261155}. Note=Cytoplasmic localization seen
CC       in neoplastic cells of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma
CC       (HNSCC) tumors. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16261155}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q5XXA6-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q5XXA6-2; Sequence=VSP_025665, VSP_025668, VSP_025669;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q5XXA6-3; Sequence=VSP_025666, VSP_025667, VSP_025668,
CC                                  VSP_025669, VSP_025670, VSP_025671;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Broadly expressed with higher levels in liver,
CC       skeletal muscle and gastrointestinal muscles.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15215166, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16906560}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The region spanning the fifth and sixth transmembrane
CC       domains probably forms the pore-forming region. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The term 'anoctamin' was coined because these
CC       channels are anion selective and have eight (OCT) transmembrane
CC       segments. There is some dissatisfaction in the field with the Ano
CC       nomenclature because it is not certain that all the members of
CC       this family are anion channels or have the 8-transmembrane
CC       topology.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the anoctamin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated chloride channel. Chloride channels have
CC       several functions including the regulation of cell volume;
CC       membrane potential stabilization, signal transduction and
CC       transepithelial transport. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P35523}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P35523}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P35523}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in skeletal muscles.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The CLC channel family contains both chloride
CC       channels and proton-coupled anion transporters that exchange
CC       chloride or another anion for protons. The absence of conserved
CC       gating glutamate residues is typical for family members that
CC       function as channels (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel (TC 2.A.49) family.
CC       ClC-1/CLCN1 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

ID   CLIC6_RAT               Reviewed;         612 AA.
AC   Q811Q2;
DT   01-FEB-2005, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   01-JUN-2003, sequence version 1.
DT   22-NOV-2017, entry version 113.
DE   RecName: Full=Chloride intracellular channel protein 6;
GN   Name=Clic6; Synonyms=Clic6b;
OS   Rattus norvegicus (Rat).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Mammalia; Eutheria; Euarchontoglires; Glires; Rodentia; Myomorpha;
OC   Muroidea; Muridae; Murinae; Rattus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=10116;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY,
RP   AND INTERACTION WITH DRD2; DRD3 AND DRD4.
RC   STRAIN=Sprague-Dawley; TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=14499480; DOI=10.1016/S0169-328X(03)00283-3;
RA   Griffon N., Jeanneteau F., Prieur F., Diaz J., Sokoloff P.;
RT   "CLIC6, a member of the intracellular chloride channel family,
RT   interacts with dopamine D(2)-like receptors.";
RL   Brain Res. Mol. Brain Res. 117:47-57(2003).
RN   [2]
RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-40; SER-264; SER-303;
RP   SER-321 AND SER-368, AND IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE
RP   SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22673903; DOI=10.1038/ncomms1871;
RA   Lundby A., Secher A., Lage K., Nordsborg N.B., Dmytriyev A.,
RA   Lundby C., Olsen J.V.;
RT   "Quantitative maps of protein phosphorylation sites across 14
RT   different rat organs and tissues.";
RL   Nat. Commun. 3:876-876(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: May insert into membranes and form chloride ion
CC       channels. May play a critical role in water-secreting cells,
CC       possibly through the regulation of chloride ion transport (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with dopamine receptors DRD2, DRD3 and DRD4.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14499480}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:14499480}; Single-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:14499480}. Note=Predominantly cytoplasmic.
CC       Upon chloride ion efflux from the cell, it is translocated to the
CC       plasma membrane (By similarity). Colocalizes with DRD3 at the
CC       plasma membrane. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominanlty expressed in brain, pituitary
CC       and stomach. In adult brain, it is restricted to the choroid
CC       plexus, the striatal proliferative subventricular zone and the
CC       cerebellum where it colocalizes with the D(3)R in the Purkinje
CC       cells of the lobules IX and X. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14499480}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Members of this family may change from a globular, soluble
CC       state to a state where the N-terminal domain is inserted into the
CC       membrane and functions as chloride channel. A conformation change
CC       of the N-terminal domain is thought to expose hydrophobic surfaces
CC       that trigger membrane insertion (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel CLIC family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [12]
RP   REVIEW, AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=22002868; DOI=10.1113/expphysiol.2011.058248;
RA   Sanders K.M., Zhu M.H., Britton F., Koh S.D., Ward S.M.;
RT   "Anoctamins and gastrointestinal smooth muscle excitability.";
RL   Exp. Physiol. 97:200-206(2012).
RN   [13]
RP   INTERACTION WITH TRPV4.
RX   PubMed=24509911; DOI=10.1096/fj.13-243436;
RA   Takayama Y., Shibasaki K., Suzuki Y., Yamanaka A., Tominaga M.;
RT   "Modulation of water efflux through functional interaction between
RT   TRPV4 and TMEM16A/anoctamin 1.";
RL   FASEB J. 28:2238-2248(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium-activated chloride channel (CaCC) which plays an
CC       important role in transepithelial anion transport and smooth
CC       muscle contraction. Required for the normal functioning of the
CC       interstitial cells of Cajal (ICCs) which generate electrical
CC       pacemaker activity in gastrointestinal smooth muscles. Acts as a
CC       major contributor to basal and stimulated chloride conductance in
CC       airway epithelial cells and plays an important role in tracheal
CC       cartilage development. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18585372,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18724360, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21908539,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22002868, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22075693}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: ATP and calmodulin are essential for its
CC       activation. Channel activity is inhibited by CFTR protein and by
CC       chloride inhibitors such as niflumic acid (NFA) and 4,4'-
CC       diisothiocyanatostilbene-2,2'-disulfonic acid (DIDS) (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Interacts with CFTR (By similarity). Interacts
CC       with TRPV4 (PubMed:24509911). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q5XXA6,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24509911}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18585372,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22075693}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}. Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q5XXA6}.
CC       Note=Cytoplasmic localization seen in neoplastic cells of head and
CC       neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) tumors.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q5XXA6}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8BHY3-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8BHY3-2; Sequence=VSP_025672;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in pulmonary bronchiole
CC       epithelial cells, pancreatic and submandibular gland acinar cells,
CC       kidney proximal tubule, all retinal cell layers, most sensory
CC       cells of dorsal root ganglia, Leydig cells and spermatocytes (at
CC       protein level). Expressed at high levels in the thyroid gland and
CC       gastrointestinal muscles. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18585372,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18724360, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20056604}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: In the developing respiratory system,
CC       expressed in epithelium of trachea and lung at E12.5 and E14.5 but
CC       not detected in distal epithelial tips. Expressed in the
CC       mesenchyme adjacent to the proximal conducting airway epithelium
CC       at E14.5 but not at E16.5. Epithelial expression persists at
CC       E16.5. At E18.5, high levels detected only in epithelial cells of
CC       terminal sacules. In the developing gastrointestinal tract,
CC       expressed in the esophageal mesenchyme and epithelium of posterior
CC       stomach and intestine. In the developing skeleton, expressed in
CC       the perichondria of the neural arch of developing vertebrae at
CC       E14.5 and E16.5. In developing skin, expression is restricted to
CC       basal layers of the epidermis at E16.5.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18729231}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The region spanning the fifth and sixth transmembrane
CC       domains probably forms the pore-forming region.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice display severe tracheomalacia with gaps
CC       in the tracheal cartilage rings along the entire length of the
CC       trachea. 90% of mutants die within the first nine days of
CC       postnatal life and no mutants survive longer than 30 days
CC       postpartum. Knockdown of Ano1 reduces calcium-activated chloride
CC       currents and saliva production. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18585372}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The term 'anoctamin' was coined because these
CC       channels are anion selective and have eight (OCT) transmembrane
CC       segments. There is some dissatisfaction in the field with the Ano
CC       nomenclature because it is not certain that all the members of
CC       this family are anion channels or have the 8-transmembrane
CC       topology.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the anoctamin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAH06062.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=BAC26230.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=BAC26398.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=BAC35051.1; Type=Erroneous translation; Note=Wrong choice of frame.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RN   [10]
RP   REVIEW, AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=21890523; DOI=10.1113/expphysiol.2011.058230;
RA   Pifferi S., Cenedese V., Menini A.;
RT   "Anoctamin 2/TMEM16B: a calcium-activated chloride channel in
RT   olfactory transduction.";
RL   Exp. Physiol. 97:193-199(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium-activated chloride channel (CaCC) which may play
CC       a role in olfactory signal transduction. Odorant molecules bind to
CC       odor-sensing receptors (OSRs), leading to an increase in calcium
CC       entry that activates CaCC current which amplifies the
CC       depolarization of the OSR cells, ANO2 seems to be the underlying
CC       chloride channel involved in this process. May mediate light
CC       perception amplification in retina. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19474308,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19475416, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19561302,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21890523, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22075693}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Channel activity is repressed by chloride
CC       inhibitors; strongly by niflumic acid (NFA), partially by
CC       flufenamic acid (FFA), and only slightly by meclofenamic acid
CC       (MFA), 5-Nitro-2-(3-phenylpropylamino)benzoic acid (NPPB), 4-
CC       acetamido-4'-isothiocyanato-stilben-2,2'-disulfonate (SITS), and
CC       4,4'-diisothiocyanatostilbene-2,2'-disulfonic acid (DIDS).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19475416}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of a presynaptic protein complex recruited to
CC       specialized plasma membrane domains of photoreceptors. Interacts
CC       with DLG4 by its C-terminal region. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19474308}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19474308,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19561302}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19474308, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19561302}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in retina, especially in the
CC       photoreceptor synaptic terminals, and in olfactory epithelium,
CC       particularly in sensory neurons (OSNs) and cilia (at protein
CC       level). Also observed in retinal pigment epithelium (RPE),
CC       olfactory bulb, brain, and cortex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19474308,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19561302, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20056604}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Detected in the mantle layer of the neural
CC       tube and in the dorsal root ganglia at E14.5. In developing skin,
CC       expression is restricted to basal layers of the epidermis at
CC       E16.5. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18729231}.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19474308}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The term 'anoctamin' was coined because these
CC       channels are anion selective and have eight (OCT) transmembrane
CC       segments. There is some dissatisfaction in the field with the Ano
CC       nomenclature because it is not certain that all the members of
CC       this family are anion channels or have the 8-transmembrane
CC       topology.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the anoctamin family.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9NQ90}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAH33409.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=BAC32073.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Probable cloning artifact.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RN   [24]
RP   INTERACTION WITH AHCYL1.
RX   PubMed=23542070; DOI=10.1053/j.gastro.2013.03.047;
RA   Park S., Shcheynikov N., Hong J.H., Zheng C., Suh S.H., Kawaai K.,
RA   Ando H., Mizutani A., Abe T., Kiyonari H., Seki G., Yule D.,

RL   Gastroenterology 145:232-241(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Apical membrane anion-exchanger with wide epithelial
CC       distribution that plays a role as a component of the pH buffering
CC       system for maintaining acid-base homeostasis. Acts as a versatile
CC       DIDS-sensitive inorganic and organic anion transporter that
CC       mediates the uptake of monovalent anions like chloride,
CC       bicarbonate, formate and hydroxyl ion and divalent anions like
CC       sulfate and oxalate. Function in multiple exchange modes involving
CC       pairs of these anions, which include chloride-bicarbonate,
CC       chloride-oxalate, oxalate-formate, oxalate-sulfate and chloride-
CC       formate exchange. Apical membrane chloride-bicarbonate exchanger
CC       that mediates luminal chloride absorption and bicarbonate
CC       secretion by the small intestinal brush border membrane and
CC       contributes to intracellular pH regulation in the duodenal upper
CC       villous epithelium during proton-coupled peptide absorption,
CC       possibly by providing a bicarbonate import pathway. Its
CC       association with carbonic anhydrase CA2 forms a bicarbonate
CC       transport metabolon; hence maximizes the local concentration of
CC       bicarbonate at the transporter site. Mediates also intestinal
CC       chloride absorption and oxalate secretion, thereby preventing
CC       hyperoxaluria and calcium oxalate urolithiasis. Transepithelial
CC       oxalate secretion, chloride-formate, chloride-oxalate and
CC       chloride-bicarbonate transport activities in the duodenum are
CC       inhibited by PKC activation in a calcium-independent manner. The
CC       apical membrane chloride-bicarbonate exchanger provides also a
CC       major route for fluid and bicarbonate secretion into the proximal
CC       tubules of the kidney as well as into the proximal part of the
CC       interlobular pancreatic ductal tree, where it mediates
CC       electrogenic chloride-bicarbonate exchange with a chloride-
CC       bicarbonate stoichiometry of 1:2, and hence will dilute and
CC       alkalinize protein-rich acinar secretion. Mediates also the
CC       transcellular sulfate absorption and oxalate secretion across the
CC       apical membrane in the duodenum and the formate ion efflux at the
CC       apical brush border of cells in the proximal tubules of kidney.
CC       Plays a role in sperm capacitation by increasing intracellular pH.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11459928, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11842009,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12119287, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12217875,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15203903, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16141316,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16532010, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16606687,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17053783, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17170027,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18046080, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18496516,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20150244, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20969732,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21976599, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22021714,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22895259}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Apical membrane chloride-bicarbonate exchange
CC       activity of the pancreatic duct is inhibited by DIDS (By
CC       similarity). Apical membrane chloride-formate exchange activity in
CC       the proximal tubules of the kidney and oxalate secretion in the
CC       duodenum are inhibited by 4,4'-diisothiocyanatostilbene-2,2'-
CC       disulfonic acid (DIDS - an inhibitor of several anion channels and
CC       transporters). {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11459928,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12119287, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12217875,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15203903, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22021714,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22895259}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=0.3 mM for oxalate, PubMed:12119287
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12119287, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15203903};
CC         KM=0.314 mM for oxalate, PubMed:15203903
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12119287, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15203903};
CC         KM=3.87 mM for formate, PubMed:15203903
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12119287, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15203903};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts (via C-terminal cytoplasmic domain) with CA2;
CC       the interaction stimulates chloride-bicarbonate exchange activity.
CC       Interacts with SLC9A3R1 (via the PDZ domains). Interacts with
CC       SLC9A3R2 (via the PDZ domains) (By similarity). Interacts (via C-
CC       terminal domain) with PDZK1 (via C-terminal PDZ domain); the
CC       interaction induces chloride and oxalate exchange transport.
CC       Interacts with CFTR, SLC26A3 and SLC9A3R1. Interacts with AHCYL1;
CC       the interaction increases SLC26A6 activity (PubMed:23542070).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9BXS9, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16141316,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21976599, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23542070}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P26361:Cftr; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-6895517, EBI-6115317;
CC       Q9WVC8:Slc26a3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-6895517, EBI-6895537;
CC       P70441:Slc9a3r1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-6895517, EBI-1184085;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Apical cell membrane;
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein. Cytoplasmic vesicle membrane; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein. Microsome. Note=Colocalized with CA2 at the
CC       surface of the cell membrane in order to form a bicarbonate
CC       transport metabolon; colocalization is reduced in phorbol
CC       myristate acetate (PMA)-induced cells (By similarity). Localized
CC       in sperm membranes. Colocalizes with CFTR at the midpiece of sperm
CC       tail. Localizes to the apical membrane brush border of epithelial
CC       cells in the proximal tubules of kidney, of enterocytes of the
CC       small intestine and of gastric parietal cells in the stomach. May
CC       be translocated from the cytosolic surface of the cell membrane to
CC       the intracellular space by PKC in phorbol myristate acetate (PMA)-
CC       induced cells. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=Slc26a6a;
CC         IsoId=Q8CIW6-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=Slc26a6b;
CC         IsoId=Q8CIW6-2; Sequence=VSP_047853;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q8CIW6-3; Sequence=VSP_047853, VSP_047854;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in kidney (at protein level). Highly
CC       expressed in stomach, kidney, heart and small intestine, low in
CC       the lung, liver, testis, brain, skeletal muscle and colon.
CC       Expressed in spermatogenic cells. Isoform 1 is expressed in
CC       intestine, kidney, testis, brain, muscle, heart, and stomach.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11459928, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11842009,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12217875, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17170027,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21976599}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated by dietary fructose intake (at protein
CC       level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18496516}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on serine residues by PKC; the phosphorylation
CC       disrupts interaction with carbonic anhydrase CA2 and reduces
CC       bicarbonate transport activity in a phorbol myristate acetate
CC       (PMA)-induced manner. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice show an important decrease in salt
CC       absorption in the intestine and failed to develop hypertension on
CC       a high-fructose diet. Show a reduction in pancreatic duct fluid
CC       and bicarbonate secretion. Show enhanced oxalate absorption in the
CC       intestine leading to hyperoxalemia and hyperoxaluria with high
CC       incidence of calcium-oxalate stones formation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16532010, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17053783,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18496516}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AC168054; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAAA01111125; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAAA01200220; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

ID   EXC4_CAEEL              Reviewed;         290 AA.
AC   Q8WQA4;
