DT   02-FEB-2004, sequence version 2.
DT   22-NOV-2017, entry version 100.
DE   RecName: Full=Chloride intracellular channel exc-4;
DE   AltName: Full=Excretory canal abnormal protein 4;
GN   Name=exc-4; ORFNames=Y105E8A.22;
OS   Caenorhabditis elegans.
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Nematoda; Chromadorea; Rhabditida;
OC   Rhabditoidea; Rhabditidae; Peloderinae; Caenorhabditis.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=6239;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY,
RP   DOMAIN, AND MUTAGENESIS OF LEU-46 AND PRO-238.
RC   STRAIN=Bristol N2;
RX   PubMed=14684823; DOI=10.1126/science.1087667;
RA   Berry K.L., Buelow H.E., Hall D.H., Hobert O.;
RT   "A C. elegans CLIC-like protein required for intracellular tube
RT   formation and maintenance.";
RL   Science 302:2134-2137(2003).
RN   [2]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].
RC   STRAIN=Bristol N2;
RX   PubMed=9851916; DOI=10.1126/science.282.5396.2012;
RG   The C. elegans sequencing consortium;
RT   "Genome sequence of the nematode C. elegans: a platform for
RT   investigating biology.";
RL   Science 282:2012-2018(1998).
RN   [3]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.6 ANGSTROMS), FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION,
RP   AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=17985355; DOI=10.1002/prot.21704;
RA   Littler D.R., Harrop S.J., Brown L.J., Pankhurst G.J., Mynott A.V.,
RA   Luciani P., Mandyam R.A., Mazzanti M., Tanda S., Berryman M.A.,
RA   Breit S.N., Curmi P.M.G.;
RT   "Comparison of vertebrate and invertebrate CLIC proteins: the crystal
RT   structures of Caenorhabditis elegans EXC-4 and Drosophila melanogaster
RT   DmCLIC.";
RL   Proteins 71:364-378(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: May insert into membranes and form chloride ion
CC       channels. Involved in the formation of the excretory canal.
CC       Required to prevent cystic lumenal expansions in the excretory
CC       cell. Not required for formation of the initial tube, but is
CC       required for regulating the size of the tube lumen as it grows.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17985355}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17985355}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Note=Exists both as soluble
CC       cytoplasmic protein and as membrane protein with probably a single
CC       transmembrane domain. Localizes to various tubular membranes in
CC       distinct cell types, including the lumenal membrane of the
CC       excretory tubes.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the secretory system, hypodermis,
CC       vulva, pharyngeal muscle, rectal gland, tubular rectal epithelium
CC       cells, and tubular neuronal support cells in the head and tail.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14684823}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The N-terminal part (1-55) is necessary and sufficient for
CC       translocation from the cytosol to the membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14684823}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Members of this family may change from a globular, soluble
CC       state to a state where the N-terminal domain is inserted into the
CC       membrane and functions as chloride channel. A conformation change
CC       of the N-terminal domain is thought to expose hydrophobic surfaces
CC       that trigger membrane insertion (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel CLIC family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RC   TISSUE=Cervix carcinoma;
RX   PubMed=20068231; DOI=10.1126/scisignal.2000475;
RA   Olsen J.V., Vermeulen M., Santamaria A., Kumar C., Miller M.L.,
RA   Jensen L.J., Gnad F., Cox J., Jensen T.S., Nigg E.A., Brunak S.,
RA   Mann M.;
RT   "Quantitative phosphoproteomics reveals widespread full
RT   phosphorylation site occupancy during mitosis.";
RL   Sci. Signal. 3:RA3-RA3(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Apical membrane anion-exchanger with wide epithelial
CC       distribution that plays a role as a component of the pH buffering
CC       system for maintaining acid-base homeostasis. Acts as a versatile
CC       DIDS-sensitive inorganic and organic anion transporter that
CC       mediates the uptake of monovalent anions like chloride,
CC       bicarbonate, formate and hydroxyl ion and divalent anions like
CC       sulfate and oxalate. Function in multiple exchange modes involving
CC       pairs of these anions, which include chloride-bicarbonate,
CC       chloride-oxalate, oxalate-formate, oxalate-sulfate and chloride-
CC       formate exchange. Apical membrane chloride-bicarbonate exchanger
CC       that mediates luminal chloride absorption and bicarbonate
CC       secretion by the small intestinal brush border membrane and
CC       contributes to intracellular pH regulation in the duodenal upper
CC       villous epithelium during proton-coupled peptide absorption,
CC       possibly by providing a bicarbonate import pathway. Mediates also
CC       intestinal chloride absorption and oxalate secretion, thereby
CC       preventing hyperoxaluria and calcium oxalate urolithiasis.
CC       Transepithelial oxalate secretion, chloride-formate, chloride-
CC       oxalate and chloride-bicarbonate transport activities in the
CC       duodenum are inhibited by PKC activation in a calcium-independent
CC       manner. The apical membrane chloride-bicarbonate exchanger
CC       provides also a major route for fluid and bicarbonate secretion
CC       into the proximal tubules of the kidney as well as into the
CC       proximal part of the interlobular pancreatic ductal tree, where it
CC       mediates electrogenic chloride-bicarbonate exchange with a
CC       chloride-bicarbonate stoichiometry of 1:2, and hence will dilute
CC       and alkalinize protein-rich acinar secretion. Mediates also the
CC       transcellular sulfate absorption and oxalate secretion across the
CC       apical membrane in the duodenum and the formate ion efflux at the
CC       apical brush border of cells in the proximal tubules of kidney.
CC       Plays a role in sperm capacitation by increasing intracellular pH.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Isoform 4: Apical membrane chloride-bicarbonate
CC       exchanger. Its association with carbonic anhydrase CA2 forms a
CC       bicarbonate transport metabolon; hence maximizes the local
CC       concentration of bicarbonate at the transporter site.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Apical membrane chloride-formate exchange
CC       activity in the proximal tubules of the kidney and oxalate
CC       secretion in the duodenum are inhibited by 4,4'-
CC       diisothiocyanatostilbene-2,2'-disulfonic acid (DIDS - an inhibitor
CC       of several anion channels and transporters) (By similarity).
CC       Apical membrane chloride-bicarbonate exchange activity of the
CC       pancreatic duct is inhibited by 4,4'-diisothiocyanatostilbene-
CC       2,2'-disulfonic acid (DIDS - an inhibitor of several anion
CC       channels and transporters). Isoform 4, isoform 5 and isoform 6
CC       chloride, bicarbonate and sulfate transport activities are
CC       inhibited by DIDS. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12444019,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990874, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20501439}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts (via C-terminal domain) with PDZK1 (via C-
CC       terminal PDZ domain); the interaction induces chloride and oxalate
CC       exchange transport. Interacts with CFTR, SLC26A3 and SLC9A3R1 (By
CC       similarity). Isoform 4 interacts (via C-terminal cytoplasmic
CC       domain) with CA2; the interaction stimulates chloride-bicarbonate
CC       exchange activity. Isoform 4 and isoform 5 interact with SLC9A3R1
CC       (via the PDZ domains). Isoform 4 and isoform 5 interact with
CC       SLC9A3R2 (via the PDZ domains). Interacts with AHCYL1; the
CC       interaction increases SLC26A6 activity (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9BXS9, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12444019,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990874}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Apical cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Cytoplasmic vesicle membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250}. Microsome {ECO:0000250}. Note=Localized in
CC       sperm membranes. Colocalizes with CFTR at the midpiece of sperm
CC       tail. Localizes to the apical membrane brush border of epithelial
CC       cells in the proximal tubules of kidney, of enterocytes of the
CC       small intestine and of gastric parietal cells in the stomach. May
CC       be translocated from the cytosolic surface of the cell membrane to
CC       the intracellular space by PKC in phorbol myristate acetate (PMA)-
CC       induced cells (By similarity). Colocalized with CA2 at the surface
CC       of the cell membrane in order to form a bicarbonate transport
CC       metabolon; colocalization is reduced in phorbol myristate acetate
CC       (PMA)-induced cells. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 4: Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Apical cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein. Basolateral cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Note=Localizes to the apical and basolateral surfaces of tubular
CC       wall cells in kidney and in the brush border of pancreatic duct
CC       cells.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 5: Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 6: Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=7;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=SLC26A6b;
CC         IsoId=Q9BXS9-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q9BXS9-2; Sequence=VSP_006169;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q9BXS9-3; Sequence=VSP_040127;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=SLC26A6a;
CC         IsoId=Q9BXS9-4; Sequence=VSP_046807, VSP_040127;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=SLC26A6c;
CC         IsoId=Q9BXS9-5; Sequence=VSP_046807, VSP_047851, VSP_040127;
CC       Name=6; Synonyms=SLC26A6d;
CC         IsoId=Q9BXS9-6; Sequence=VSP_046807, VSP_047852;
CC       Name=7;
CC         IsoId=Q9BXS9-7; Sequence=VSP_055273, VSP_055274;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Ubiquitous. Highest levels in kidney and
CC       pancreas. Lower expression in heart, skeletal muscle, liver and
CC       placenta. Also found in lung and brain. Isoform 4 is ubiquitously
CC       expressed. Isoform 6 is expressed in heart, brain, placenta, lung,
CC       liver, kidney, pancreas, spleen, thymus, prostate, testis and
CC       ovary. Isoform 5 is expressed weakly in placenta, lung, liver and
CC       pancreas. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11087667,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11247665}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Down-regulated by pro-inflammatory cytokine IFN gamma.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18655181}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on serine residues by PKC; the phosphorylation
CC       disrupts interaction with carbonic anhydrase CA2 and reduces
CC       bicarbonate transport activity in a phorbol myristate acetate
CC       (PMA)-induced manner. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990874}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SLC26A/SulP transporter (TC 2.A.53)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC         IsoId=Q9C0H2-4; Sequence=VSP_042220;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in excitable tissues. Expressed in
CC       the brain, heart, skeletal muscle, colon, spleen, kidney and
CC       peripheral blood leukocytes. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15010458}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15010458,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19159218}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The current is completely inhibited by the addition
CC       of an anion permeability inhibitor. Addition of a Ca(2+) ionophore
CC       induces an outward-rectified current in mock-transfected cells,
CC       but it introduced an overt linear current in TTYH3-transfected
CC       cells.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the tweety family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       GABRA4 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. Associates with alpha and beta
CC       subunits (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       GABRE sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [10]
RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=20335315; DOI=10.1152/ajprenal.00030.2010;
RA   Wegner B., Al-Momany A., Kulak S.C., Kozlowski K., Obeidat M.,
RA   Jahroudi N., Paes J., Berryman M., Ballermann B.J.;

RN   [11]
RP   FUNCTION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND INVOLVEMENT IN DFNB103.
RX   PubMed=24781754; DOI=10.1038/ejhg.2014.83;
RA   Seco C.Z., Oonk A.M., Dominguez-Ruiz M., Draaisma J.M., Gandia M.,
RA   Oostrik J., Neveling K., Kunst H.P., Hoefsloot L.H., Del Castillo I.,
RA   Pennings R.J., Kremer H., Admiraal R.J., Schraders M.;
RT   "Progressive hearing loss and vestibular dysfunction caused by a
RT   homozygous nonsense mutation in CLIC5.";
RL   Eur. J. Hum. Genet. 23:189-194(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for normal hearing (PubMed:24781754). It is
CC       necessary for the formation of stereocilia in the inner ear and
CC       normal development of the organ of Corti (By similarity). Can
CC       insert into membranes and form poorly selective ion channels that
CC       may also transport chloride ions. May play a role in the
CC       regulation of transepithelial ion absorption and secretion. Is
CC       required for the development and/or maintenance of the proper
CC       glomerular endothelial cell and podocyte architecture
CC       (PubMed:15184393, PubMed:18028448, PubMed:20335315).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8BXK9, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15184393,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18028448, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20335315,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24781754}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of a multimeric complex consisting of several
CC       cytoskeletal proteins, including actin, ezrin, alpha-actinin,
CC       gelsolin, and IQGAP1. Interacts with AKAP9.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12163479, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18028448}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P00523:SRC (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-5658997, EBI-848039;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 1: Cytoplasm, cell cortex
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15184393}. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15184393}. Membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15184393}; Single-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15184393}. Note=Associates with the cortical
CC       actin cytoskeleton. Exists both as soluble cytoplasmic protein and
CC       as membrane protein with probably a single transmembrane domain
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 2: Golgi apparatus. Cytoplasm,
CC       cytoskeleton, microtubule organizing center, centrosome. Membrane;
CC       Single-pass membrane protein. Note=Colocalized with AKAP9 at the
CC       Golgi apparatus as well as, to a lesser extent, the centrosome.
CC       Exists both as soluble cytoplasmic protein and as membrane protein
CC       with probably a single transmembrane domain (By similarity).
CC       Colocalized with podocalyxin in renal glomeruli. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=CLIC5B;
CC         IsoId=Q9NZA1-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=CLIC5A;
CC         IsoId=Q9NZA1-2; Sequence=VSP_000869, VSP_000870;
CC         Note=Ref.1 (AAF66928) sequence is in conflict in position:
CC         12:R->S. {ECO:0000305};
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q9NZA1-3; Sequence=VSP_044889, VSP_044890, VSP_044891;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widely expressed in both fetal and adult human
CC       tissues (PubMed:24781754). Isoform 1 is expressed in renal
CC       glomeruli endothelial cells and podocytes (at protein level).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20335315, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24781754}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Members of this family may change from a globular, soluble
CC       state to a state where the N-terminal domain is inserted into the
CC       membrane and functions as chloride channel. A conformation change
CC       of the N-terminal domain is thought to expose hydrophobic surfaces
CC       that trigger membrane insertion (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Deafness, autosomal recessive, 103 (DFNB103)
CC       [MIM:616042]: A form of sensorineural deafness with onset in early
CC       childhood. Hearing impairment progresses from mild to severe or
CC       even profound before the second decade, and is accompanied by
CC       vestibular areflexia. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24781754}. Note=The
CC       disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in
CC       this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel CLIC family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

GN   ORFNames=T27E9.9 {ECO:0000312|WormBase:T27E9.9};

RT   Caenorhabditis elegans.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 280:6392-6398(2005).
RN   [2] {ECO:0000312|Proteomes:UP000001940}
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].

RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=26705699; DOI=10.7554/eLife.12432;
RA   Pereira L., Kratsios P., Serrano-Saiz E., Sheftel H., Mayo A.E.,
RA   Hall D.H., White J.G., LeBoeuf B., Garcia L.R., Alon U., Hobert O.;
RT   "A cellular and regulatory map of the cholinergic nervous system of C.
RT   elegans.";
RL   Elife 4:12432-12477(2015).
RN   [4] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=27782882; DOI=10.7554/eLife.21734;
RA   Takayanagi-Kiya S., Zhou K., Jin Y.;
RT   "Release-dependent feedback inhibition by a presynaptically localized
RT   ligand-gated anion channel.";
RL   Elife 5:21734-21749(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probable acetylcholine-gated chloride channel subunit
CC       (PubMed:15579462). Does not have ion channel activity alone as a
CC       homopentamer, but forms a functional heteropentameric ion channel
CC       with acc-1 (PubMed:15579462). May function with lgc-46 to regulate
CC       synaptic transmission and synaptic vesicle release in response to
CC       acetylcholine in cholinergic motor neurons (PubMed:27782882).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Does not form a functional homopentameric ion channel.
CC       Forms a functional heteropentameric ion channel composed of acc-1
CC       and acc-4. May interact with acc-2; the interaction does not
CC       result in significant heteropentameric ion channel activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, presynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}. Cell projection, axon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in all cholinergic motor neurons
CC       except for ASJ and RIB neurons. Also expressed in AVF neurons.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26705699}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Grossly normal movement. In addition, in
CC       response to induced acetylcholine release, there is prolonged and
CC       slow decay of excitory postsynaptic currents which results in
CC       increased release of synaptic vesicles during that late phase of
CC       synaptic vesicle release in cholinergic motor neurons. Knockout in
CC       an lgc-46 gain of function mutant background suppresses the slow
CC       locomotion defect in the single lgc-46 gain of function mutant.
CC       Knockout together with gain of function mutations in lgc-46 and
CC       acr-2 suppresses the convulsion defects in the double lgc-46 and
CC       acr-2 double gain of function mutant.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Maleszka R., Hanes S.D., Hackett R.L., de Couet H.G., Miklos G.L.G.;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Non-essential protein that probably acts as a chloride
CC       channel. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Flies lacking tty are viable and fertile.
CC       Was named 'tweety' after the cartoon character that cannot fly.
CC       Indeed, a mutant involving a genomic region that contain tty leads
CC       to flies that cannot fly. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8552658}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the tweety family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=17601953; DOI=10.1242/jeb.006361;
RA   Rose U., Derst C., Wanischeck M., Marinc C., Walther C.;
RT   "Properties and possible function of a hyperpolarisation-activated
RT   chloride current in Drosophila.";
RL   J. Exp. Biol. 210:2489-2500(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated chloride channel. Chloride channels have
CC       several functions including the regulation of cell volume;
CC       membrane potential stabilization, signal transduction and
CC       transepithelial transport. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17601953}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000255}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=6;
CC       Name=D {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10731132};
CC         IsoId=Q9VGH7-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. {ECO:0000305};
CC       Name=A {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10731132};
CC         IsoId=Q9VGH7-2; Sequence=VSP_052366;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. {ECO:0000305};
CC       Name=F; Synonyms=B;
CC         IsoId=Q9VGH7-3; Sequence=VSP_052367;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=C {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10731132};
CC         IsoId=Q9VGH7-4; Sequence=VSP_052366, VSP_052367;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. {ECO:0000305};
CC       Name=G;
CC         IsoId=Q9VGH7-6; Sequence=VSP_035041, VSP_035042, VSP_052367;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=H;
CC         IsoId=Q9VGH7-7; Sequence=VSP_035041, VSP_035042;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: At embryonic stages 13-16, expressed in a
CC       subset of the midline cells of the midline primordium and in all
CC       of the midline glia. Expressed along the Z-line of the sarcomere
CC       in larval longitudinal muscles. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15501232,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17601953}.
CC   -!- RNA EDITING: Modified_positions=249 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12537569,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17018572}, 276 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12537569,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17018572}, 285 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12537569,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17018572}, 286 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12537569,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17018572}; Note=Partially edited. Target of
CC       Adar. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17018572};
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The CLC channel family contains both chloride
CC       channels and proton-coupled anion transporters that exchange
CC       chloride or another anion for protons. The absence of conserved
CC       gating glutamate residues is typical for family members that
CC       function as channels.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel (TC 2.A.49) family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.8 ANGSTROMS), SUBUNIT, FUNCTION, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=16176272; DOI=10.1111/j.1742-4658.2005.04909.x;
RA   Littler D.R., Assaad N.N., Harrop S.J., Brown L.J., Pankhurst G.J.,

RN   [23]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.2 ANGSTROMS), AND DOMAIN.
RX   PubMed=16581025; DOI=10.1016/j.bbrc.2006.03.099;
RA   Li Y., Li D., Zeng Z., Wang D.;
RT   "Trimeric structure of the wild soluble chloride intracellular ion
RT   channel CLIC4 observed in crystals.";
RL   Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 343:1272-1278(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Can insert into membranes and form poorly selective ion
CC       channels that may also transport chloride ions. Channel activity
CC       depends on the pH. Membrane insertion seems to be redox-regulated
CC       and may occur only under oxydizing conditions. Promotes cell-
CC       surface expression of HRH3. Has alternate cellular functions like
CC       a potential role in angiogenesis or in maintaining apical-
CC       basolateral membrane polarity during mitosis and cytokinesis.
CC       Could also promote endothelial cell proliferation and regulate
CC       endothelial morphogenesis (tubulogenesis).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12163372, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14569596,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16176272, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16239224,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18302930, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19247789}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of a multimeric complex consisting of several
CC       cytoskeletal proteins, including actin, ezrin, alpha-actinin,
CC       gelsolin, IQGAP1 and CLIC5A. Binds directly to brain dynamin I in
CC       a complex containing actin, tubulin and 14-3-3 isoforms. Monomer.
CC       Interacts with HRH3. Interacts with AKAP9.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10793131, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12163479,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16176272, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18302930}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, microtubule
CC       organizing center, centrosome. Cytoplasmic vesicle membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Nucleus
CC       matrix. Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}. Mitochondrion. Cell junction. Note=Colocalized with
CC       AKAP9 at the centrosome and midbody. Exists both as soluble
CC       cytoplasmic protein and as membrane protein with probably a single
CC       transmembrane domain. Present in an intracellular vesicular
CC       compartment that likely represent trans-Golgi network vesicles.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in epithelial cells from colon,
CC       esophagus and kidney (at protein level). Expression is prominent
CC       in heart, kidney, placenta and skeletal muscle.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10793131, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17200346,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17636002}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated by calcium ions in differentiating
CC       keratinocytes. Up-regulated in myofibroblasts.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12163372, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17636002}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Members of this family may change from a globular, soluble
CC       state to a state where the N-terminal domain is inserted into the
CC       membrane and functions as chloride channel. A conformation change
CC       of the N-terminal domain is thought to expose hydrophobic surfaces
CC       that trigger membrane insertion. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16581025}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the chloride channel CLIC family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Atlas of Genetics and Cytogenetics in Oncology
CC       and Haematology;
CC       URL="http://atlasgeneticsoncology.org/Genes/CLIC4ID40102ch1p36.html";
